You need to prepare the ammonia complex first, and not directly adding the NaOH to the copper sulfate because Cu(OH)2 is quite unstable and tends to decompose into CuO so, since the ammonia complex is thermodynamically more stable, that intermediate step prevents copper hydroxide's decomposition to some extent

I've been playing around with adding NaOH soln directly to CuSO4 soln.

Initially, I had been making Sodium (via the Mg + NaOH process).

When dumped into a jar of water, the Na reacts as normal.

When left to settle, a white, fluffy precipitate was left (which I assumed to be insoluble MgO).

I assumed the "water" was now a weak solution of NaOH. Adding this to CuSO4 soln, a light-blue precipitate is formed (which I assume to be Copper Hydroxide - see video link)

So I tried to make more Copper Hydroxide using stronger solutions of NaOH and CuSO4.

But as suggested in this video, I didn't get the same result. A DARK blue, slimy precipitate is formed.

At first I thought this was just excess copper sulphate, but I washed it in distilled water and it still formed a dark blue precipitate.

Does anyone know what is happening? Is this some form of complex? Perhaps because of excess Cu or NaOH?

I'm going to rerun this with much more diluted NaOH solution to see if it makes a difference.

I know it's an old vid, but when I worked on making copper complexes, I ran in to info that the sodium hydroxide direct to copper sulfate turns to copper oxide, at least partially, due to the strong ph. You have to have an excess of copper sulfate, and add a more dilute NaOH slowly, then it will precipitate smoothly. On the flip side, if you add a large enough excess of NaOH, it will actually form a sodium copper hydroxide complex salt that will redissolve and if I remember right, is very dark blue, almost black, similar to the ammonia complex, but is a little different if you look at the 2 by eye. Hope it helps someone.

5:10 I dug out a publication explaining the transformation of Cu(OH)2 to CuO in alkaline solutions:
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1293255803002140


It explains that in alkaline water, copper is dissolved as a complex Cu(OH)4 2- anion, which is sort of a precursor to the formation of CuO.
"a condensation phenomenon, combined with a loss of two hydroxyl ions and one water molecule, lead to the formation of chains of square planar CuO4 groups and then to solid CuO."


I've precipitated Cu(OH)2 from copper sulfate with NaOH 10 years ago in elementary school and the next day it was all brown/black. I never knew why that happened until now that I somehow bumped into this subject again and got really intrigued and decided to find some sources.
It's also interesting to note that if you calculated the gibbs free energy for Cu(OH)2 --> CuO + H2O, at least with the data I used, it should only be favored at above 1200 °C, but clearly it happens at much lower temperatures (one TGA curve I found showed the mass loss at around 185 °C), so not sure where I fucked up with the calculation or what's the reason.

I can actually explain why it's better to add ammonia before precipitating the Cu(OH)2 with NaOH.  The reaction of hexaaquacopper(II) to copper hydroxide is much faster than the reaction of tetraamminediaquacopper(II) to copper hydroxide (NH3 is a stronger ligand donor than H2O, making it a bit harder to pull off the metal center), and so impurities accidentally get trapped inside the product.  If you first make the ammine complex, then the precipitation is slower, allowing for a purer precipitate!  It's the same concept as recrystallization: if you're patient and let a crystal grow slowly, it will be more regular and pure than if you had just boiled off your solvent or something.

The reason why the solution turns black if you add NaOH directly to CuSO4 is because it is an acid/base reaction that produces a lot of localized heating. The higher temperature favors the oxidation of the copper to CuO (black precipitate).

Problem with direct reaction between CuSO4 and NaOH is that you form [Cu(OH)4]2- complex due to amphoteric properties of copper. Reaction also capture some CO2 and form CuCO3. And finally Cu(OH)2 is not very stable and easily oxidize however presence of [Cu(NH3)4]2+ complex stabilized copper(II) hydroxide.

It's interesting that the direct precipitation reaction caused a problem. Maybe the precipitation of Cu(OH)2 from the complex ion solution is less exothermic? I know copper hydroxide dehydrates to CuO readily with even mild heating, which would explain the black color.

It may also be that the ammonia complexes other metal ions in the (apparently impure) CuSO4 solution that otherwise form insoluble hydroxides that contaminate the product and alter its consistency.

Anyway, I love the color of the copper compounds at every stage of the reaction. I always forget how striking those blues are, even though I've seen and performed reactions with them dozens, if not hundreds, of times by now.
